Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back and legs at side completely eroded; underside deeply incised with a vertically arranged hieroglyphic inscription; pierced lengthwise; poor remains of yellow glaze; in very light yellow, cream paste; very worn and incomplete.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The inscription meaning meaning the gift of Amun could be a prophylactic motto or the private name Pa-imen. Though there is no direct parallel published in Gorton typology, this scarab could belong to a type which was distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially in Greece and Punic sites (Gorton 1996, 129-131, type XXXVI). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.110) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather poor, back broken and worn
